bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: In 1848 Simeon Brooks of Chester, Connecticut, began the manufacture of wood screw eyes and screws. Merritt Brooks, Simeon's son, developed the first machine to bend screw eyes automatically. The business prospered and in 1857 the Brooks' built a factory in Chester. After Simeon's death in 1864, Merritt continued the business until 1874, when he leased the factory to his brother-in-law William N. Clark. Merritt again assumed control of the business in February 1886 and soon his sons, Hilton C. and Simeon S., joined the business. Hilton Brooks acquired sole interest in the business in 1916. When Hilton's sons, Louis M. and Malcolm G., came into the business it was incorporated as M.S. Brooks & Sons. Hilton died in 1934, leaving his two sons in charge.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of twelve volumes of financial ledgers and accounts as well as some product illustrations.
